Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Uncovering the Myths of Unlikelihood: Granger Graphical Models for Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time-Series Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to develop effective approaches to anomaly detection from high-dimensional time series data, motivated by applications such as oil drilling, semiconductor fabrication, and railroad operation.
The proposed approach takes advantage of Granger Graphical models, which uncover the temporal dependencies between variables, to efficiently compute a robust correlation anomaly score for each variable and obtain insights regarding the causes of anomalies. The project develops effective approaches to addresses several specific challenges that arise in real-world applications of anomaly detection, including (1) nonlinear temporal dependencies; (2) hidden variables; and (3) massive amounts of data. The resulting algorithms will be evaluated on two real production systems: an oil-field mechanical system and a semi-conductor fabrication system.

The project is expected to advance the state of the art in anomaly detection for high-dimensional time series data that arise in many application domains. It offers research-based training opportunities at the intersection of machine learning, data mining, and intelligent production management, as well as operational research in general.Workshops and mini-courses will be organized to introduce advanced machine learning techniques to students, practitioners, and researchers in production management. The anomaly detection code and data sets will be freely disseminated to the broader research and educational community. Additional information about the project can be found at: http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~liu32/ggm.htm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aims to develop effective and scalable solutions to anomaly detection from high-dimensional time series data, motivated by applications such as production systems (e.g., oil drilling and production, semi-conductor fabrication) and health care (e.g., intensive critical care unit and mobile health devices).

Our research outcomes have significantly improved the state-of-art of anomaly detection for high-dimensional time series data, as well as their performance in practical applications in oil drilling/production systems and health care.

The proposed approach takes advantage of Granger Graphical models, which uncover the temporal dependencies between variables, to efficiently compute a robust correlation anomaly score for each variable and obtain insights regarding the causes of anomalies. Effective approaches have been developed to address several specific challenges that arise in real-world applications of anomaly detection, including (1) copula-based solutions for nonlinear temporal dependencies; (2) sparse and low-rank decomposition solutions for hidden variables; and (3) parallel stochastic gradient descent for massive amounts of data. In addition, a series of advanced machine learning models have been developed for detecting other types of anomalies in high-dimensional time series, such as group anomaly detection models based on mixed membership stochastic blockmodels, and an interactive interpretable anomaly detection framework based on reinforcement learning. Furthermore, tensor-based solutions have been developed for spatial-temporal data analysis and prediction. The resulting models are evaluated on three real world applications, including oil-field mechanical system monitoring, social media anomaly detection, and patient monitoring in intensive care units.  

Results of the project were disseminated through classes taught at University of Southern California and public tutorials and talks. The investigator has co-organized two workshops on large-scale time series learning and mining in top conferences of data mining. The code of the developed machine learning models is freely disseminated at http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~liu32/code.html. A data repository has been created and shared freely at http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~liu32/data.html.  The developed solutions based on Granger graphical models are adopted by industries, such as ExxonMobil and IBM. One PhD dissertation as an outcome of this project was awarded KDD Best Dissertation Award Honorable Mention in 2016.
